questions.question: What are semantic HTML elements and why are they important?
questions.answer:
Semantic HTML elements provide meaning to the structure of web content:
- Improves accessibility for screen readers
- Better SEO optimization
- Clearer code organization

Key elements include:
- <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>
- <section>, <aside>, <footer>
- <figure>, <figcaption>
- <time>, <mark>, <details>

questions.question: Explain key HTML5 APIs and their use cases
questions.answer:
HTML5 introduced several powerful APIs:
1. LocalStorage/SessionStorage
- Client-side data storage
- Key-value pair system

2. Canvas/WebGL
- 2D/3D graphics rendering
- Game development

3. Web Workers
- Background processing
- Multi-threading

4. Geolocation
- Location-based services
- Maps integration

questions.question: Which HTML5 semantic element would be most appropriate for a page's navigation menu?
questions.explanation: <nav> is specifically designed for major navigation blocks. While <header> could contain navigation, <nav> is more semantic for pure navigation. <menu> is for command menus, and <sidebar> isn't a valid HTML element.

questions.question: Compare and contrast LocalStorage, SessionStorage, and Cookies. When would you use each?
questions.answer:
Storage Options Comparison:

1. LocalStorage:
- Persists until explicitly cleared
- ~5MB storage limit
- Never sent to server
- Accessible across tabs/windows

2. SessionStorage:
- Persists for session only
- Cleared when tab closes
- Isolated to single tab
- ~5MB storage limit

3. Cookies:
- Sent with every HTTP request
- ~4KB size limit
- Can set expiration date
- Can be secured with flags (HttpOnly, Secure)

Use Cases:
- LocalStorage: User preferences, cache
- SessionStorage: Form data, page position
- Cookies: Authentication, tracking

questions.question: Which HTML5 input type provides built-in email validation?
questions.explanation:
<input type="email"> provides:
- Built-in email format validation
- Appropriate mobile keyboard
- Better accessibility
- No need for custom validation patterns
- Compatible with form validation API

questions.question: Explain Web Components and their core technologies. How do they differ from framework components?
questions.answer:
Web Components consist of three main technologies:

1. Custom Elements:
- Create new HTML elements
- Define custom behavior
- Extend existing elements

2. Shadow DOM:
- Encapsulated DOM tree
- Scoped styling
- Isolation from main document

3. HTML Templates:
- Define reusable markup
- Inert until instantiated
- Cloneable content

Differences from Framework Components:
- Framework-agnostic
- Native browser support
- True encapsulation
- No build step required
- Longer-term stability

questions.question: Explain the HTML5 History API and its common use cases.
questions.answer:
The History API allows manipulation of browser history and URLs:

1. Key Methods:
- pushState(state, title, url)
- replaceState(state, title, url)
- back(), forward(), go()

2. Events:
- popstate event
- hashchange event

3. Use Cases:
- Single Page Applications (SPAs)
- Custom navigation
- State management
- Deep linking

Example:
history.pushState({ page: 2 }, 'Title', '/page2');
window.addEventListener('popstate', handleNavigation);

questions.question: Which ARIA role should be used for a modal dialog box?
questions.explanation:
role="dialog" is correct because:
- Indicates modal context to screen readers
- Can be combined with aria-modal="true"
- Follows W3C accessibility guidelines
- Properly conveys interaction model
- Can be enhanced with aria-labelledby

questions.question: What are the key HTML attributes and techniques for optimizing image loading?
questions.answer:
Image Loading Optimization Techniques:

1. Loading Attributes:
- loading="lazy"
- decoding="async"
- fetchpriority="high|low"

2. Responsive Images:
- srcset and sizes
- <picture> element
- art direction

3. Performance Attributes:
- width and height (prevents layout shift)
- aspect-ratio
- content-visibility

4. Best Practices:
- Use WebP with fallbacks
- Proper image dimensions
- Compression optimization
- CDN usage
